prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for immediately stopping sex after my boyfriend of 11 years lets go of my hair that he has decided would be good to use as reins?
We all know porn can mislead men (And women I suppose) into thinking women are so into everything. Anyone with eyeballs can see that the woman is definitely NOT into all of it. Yes they are acting but it is extremely hard to ignore the expressions of pain, unless you choose to ignore it. Anyways there seems to be a style of porn where men are overly aggressive and choose to grab women's hair and use it as leverage.
We had been going at it for a good ten minutes already and upon switching it up he grabbed my hair, which he has never done before. 
 In my instance my neck cocked in an extremely awkward way and it was hard to make a sound. I have very long hair and he grabbed all the way up by my head twisting my head back. The sounds 
I was making were me trying to say stop but it just sounded like gags.
This went on for like 2 minutes. Eventually he loosened his grip and I immediately snapped around and pushed him way the f off me. I was disgusted. I felt violated in the sense that to me, in my opinion, there is ZERO chance he thought I was enjoying it. But he says he thought I was. He didn't get why I would react like that. And it turned into me "not communicating properly" and therefore "rejecting" him. It hurt his feelings that I didn't want to continue. So ladies, AITA? Men, AITA? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author of the story is in the wrong after stopping sex when her boyfriend grabbed her hair in a way that felt aggressive. 

First, the context: The couple has been together 11 years. During sex, the boyfriend starts grabbing her hair in a way that twists her head back, causing physical discomfort. The woman immediately stops the activity, feels violated, and the boyfriend is confused, thinking she didn't communicate properly and took it personally.

So, the key points here are consent and communication. The woman felt uncomfortable and stopped the action right away. She says he didn't think she was enjoying it, but he claims he thought she was. The boyfriend didn't realize the action was problematic until she pushed him away. 

In any sexual activity, consent is essential, and it's an ongoing process. If one partner is uncomfortable or wants to stop, they have the right to do so immediately. The woman's reaction seems appropriate given the physical discomfort and the feeling of violation. The boyfriend, on the other hand, didn't recognize the discomfort and continued, which is a communication breakdown. He's placing the blame on her for not communicating properly, but if the action caused pain or discomfort, the onus is on the person performing the action to check in and stop if necessary. 

The fact that the woman immediately stopped and expressed her discomfort (even if through non-verbal cues like pushing him away) shows she was trying to communicate. The boyfriend's hurt feelings come after she felt violated, which seems out of place. The priority should be her well-being and consent. 

So, the author isn't in the wrong. The boyfriend's actions were inappropriate, and the author acted correctly by stopping the activity.
